isis.stitle: TSI 06-12-25 - Lube Oil Recommendations for International® Diesel Engines

subjectgroup.subject: Lube Oil Recommendations for International® Diesel Engines

geninfo.para: On October 15, 2006, the American Petroleum Institute (API) licensed a new oil service category: API CJ-4.
The American Petroleum Institute (API) defines engine oil quality by service categories that define oil performance measured in standardized engine tests.

svcproc.title: Engine Oil Quality and Service Categories

item.para: API "C" categories (CH-4, CI-4, CI-4 PLUS, and CJ-4) describe oils for diesel engines.
API oils with both "C" and "S" categories (CJ-4/SM) are suitable for both spark ignition and diesel engines.

svcproc.title: API Service Category CJ-4
svcproc.para: Service Category CJ-4 describes oils for use in high-speed four stroke diesel engines designed to meet 2007 model year on highway exhaust emission standards. CJ-4 oils are compounded for use in pre-2007 engines with vehicles using fuel ranging in sulfur content up to 500 ppm (0.05% by weight).

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, the oil drain interval should be reduced by 50% if CJ-4 oil is used in pre-2007 engines with greater than 15 ppm sulfur (non-USLD) diesel fuel.

note.para: API CJ-4 oils provide protection against the following:

item.para: Soot related viscosity increase, deposits, and wear

svcproc.para: API CJ-4 oils exceed the performance criteria of API CI-4, CI-4 PLUS, CH-4, CG-4, and CF-4 and can effectively lubricate engines calling for those service categories.

Engine oils that meet API Service Category API CJ-4 have been tested in accordance with the American Chemistry Council (ACC) Code and may use the API Base Oil Interchangeability Guideline and the API Guidelines for SAE Viscosity-Grade Engine testing.

svcproc.title: Recommended API Service Categories for Pre-2007 Diesel Engines
svcproc.para: API oils CJ-4, CI-4, CI-4 PLUS, CI-4/SM are recommended for the following engines:

item.para: International® DT 466, DT 570, and HT 570 (with EGR)

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, the oil drain interval should be reduced by 50% if CJ-4 oil is used in pre-2007 engines with greater than 15 ppm sulfur (non-USLD) diesel fuel.

svcproc.title: Global DHD-1 Heavy-duty Diesel Engine Oils for Pre-2007 Diesel Engines
svcproc.para: The following associations have developed Global DHD-1 guidelines for heavy-duty diesel engine oils:
Global DHD-1 provides consistent oil performance worldwide. When API oils (excluding CJ-4) are not available, Global DHD-1 is preferred.

svcproc.title: API Service Category CJ-4 for 2007 International® MaxxForce™ Diesel Engines
svcproc.para: API CJ-4 oils are required for International® MaxxForce™ Diesel Engines with advanced exhaust aftertreatment systems that meet 2007 on-highway exhaust emission standards.

API CJ-4 oil, in combination with Ultra Low Sulfur Diesel (ULSD) fuel 0.0015% (15 ppm), is required to maintain performance and durability of aftertreatment systems meeting 2007 diesel emission regulations.

svcproc.title: Oil Viscosity

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, use the correct SAE viscosity grade oil for recommended temperature ranges.

figure.caption: Figure 2. SAE viscosity grades and temperature ranges for 2007 engines

svcproc.para: The Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) defines oil viscosity (thickness) by viscosity grade. Colder temperatures require lower grade viscosity oils for good flow during starting. Higher temperatures require higher grade viscosity oils for satisfactory lubrication.
Shaded areas in Figure 2 indicate the preferred oil for an expected temperature range.

item.para: SAE 15W-40 is the preferred oil viscosity grade, when temperatures are consistently above -7 °C (+20 °F).
Higher viscosity grade oils 15W-40 and 5W-40 are required for heavy duty driving or trailer towing.
Higher viscosity grade oils 15W-40 and 5W-40 are recommended for temperatures over 10 °C (50 °F).
A block heater is required, when temperatures are below -23 °C (-10 °F).
Some increase in oil consumption may be expected if SAE 0W-30, 10W-30 or 0W-40 oils are used.
Do not use low viscosity SAE 10W-30 or 0W-40 oils, if the temperature is consistently above +10 °C (+50 °F).

note.para: Low viscosity or winter grade oils are desirable for low temperature operation. Check oil level frequently.

item.para: Synthetic or refined oil may be used if they meet API service categories and SAE viscosity grades.
Using synthetic oil does not permit extending recommended drain intervals or filter change intervals.

note.para: See Engine Operation and Maintenance Manual for SAE viscosity grades and temperature ranges for pre-2007 engines.
